Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Advanced Reaction Control System (RCS) for CubeSat and Microsatellite Platforms
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to open new orbital flight regimes to CubeSat and microsatellite vehicles. Vehicles of these size classes are currently constrained by the lack of suitable propulsion options or additional regulatory burdens that most propulsion systems levy on rideshare vehicles. Most small satellites in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) would benefit from propulsion systems and all missions beyond LEO require on-board propulsion. The proposed Reaction Control System (RCS) architecture would enable new beyond-LEO missions for small satellites and enhance the on-orbit lifetime and utility of LEO missions at lower costs. <br/><br/>This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project ties satellite propulsion performance to the ever-increasing capabilities of small satellite Electrical and Power Systems (EPS) with a novel, miniaturized resistojet design and benign green propellant. While other technologies (batteries, solar panels, power distribution systems) have improved satellite EPS, propulsion systems have lagged. The use of a miniature resistojet in the RCS design allows the performance of the propulsion system to be decoupled from the chemical properties of propellant (largely fixed due to chemistry limitations), and instead links performance to improved EPS systems. Additionally, the proposed RCS uses a novel non-gaseous pressurization system and a benign green propellant for improved safety on ridesharing satellites.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Goose RCS team consisted of Maverick Space Systems and the CubeSat Lab at Cal Poly of San Luis Obispo, California. During the STTR period of performance, the Goose reaction control system (RCS) for small satellites was developed conceptually, designed to meet user specifications, and tested at a prototype level. The market fit for the design concept of a non-pressurized, non-hazardous, reaction control system for small satellites was also validated through customer discovery interviews that the team undertook.

As part of system development, the team developed thermodynamic models of the system as well as process diagrams, pseudocode software control algorithms, and electrical schematics. The team internally reviewed these design products through rigorous preliminary and critical design reviews, and then constructed prototype hardware and software to verify the teams’ models and designs.

This prototype hardware was manufactured and tested at the piece-part level and then integrated into a complete unit for hot-fire testing. Hot-fire testing was successfully completed in a simulated space environment, further validating the system models and design. This prototype proved out the pressure cycle of the system and pointed to areas where the design could be improved.

The team also designed a second prototype system which closely resembles a flight unit. The primary purpose of this prototype article was to pathfind manufacturing and allow demonstrations of additional hardware and software features not present in the first prototype.

The Goose RCS team accomplished significant advancements in the Phase I effort which they believe will begin to enable the Small Satellite and New Space communities to utilize this propulsion system on a broader scale, while also serving the science, education, and military communities and their in-space technological abilities.


Last Modified: 09/29/2021
Modified by: David M Hobbs
